Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Enabling Sustainable Civil Infrastructure Using Interactive Formal Analytics for Structural Health Diagnosis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks a holistic approach to real-time asset management of critical infrastructure through an as-yet unexplored intersection amongst structural health monitoring (SHM), and computational formal methods, while considering human interaction in the process. A multidisciplinary team brings computer scientists together with civil engineers experienced in structural health monitoring of real-world highway bridges. The research departs from the conventional approach to infrastructure health monitoring by direct solution of a structural model through application of a Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) solver to mechanics-based constraints. The main objective of the project is to validate the efficacy of this formal approach to structural health diagnostics. This activity involves development of a framework to construct generalized and structure-specific constraints and encode them logically using SMT to formally bound the solution space of a measurement-based structural model satisfying the inverse Eigen problem that is central to vibration-based monitoring. Interpretation of the diagnostics result based on SMT will also be investigated, in a preliminary study of the role of interactive visual analytics utilizing tangible interaction to enhance the ability of practitioners to perceive, understand, and contribute to the diagnosis of the structural health monitoring system.

Maintaining the safety of bridges and other aging civil infrastructure is a challenging societal problem. Structural health monitoring offers a sustainable pathway by maximizing the service life and informing optimized schedule-based maintenance of our costly critical infrastructure without jeopardizing public safety or the functionality of commercial and strategic highway routes. If successful, this project will create solid foundations for a comprehensive diagnosis and prognostication framework. This model for smart infrastructure is directly translatable to a broad spectrum of other cyber-physical systems. To facilitate data sharing and dissemination, the laboratory bridge model is to be distributed as an open-source resource to the broader scientific and engineering communities with experimental details, analytical models, and datasets published and maintained through the NSF NEEShub Project Warehouse. Activities to integrate the project research with education include development of course modules, projects, and case studies.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the more prevalent methods for monitoring the structural health of large civil infrastructure is through the use of distributed networks of accelerometers to measure the dynamic properties of the structure, which are sensitive to the presence and severity of damage and deterioration.  In order to relate the measured dynamic properties to the engineering properties of specific components to facilitate diagnosis of the structural damage for decision making, uncertain parameters in a numerical model of the structure are updated such that the model produces optimal correlation with the measured response.  However, any errors or uncertainty in the measurements or the numerical model can significantly affect the confidence in the identified structural parameters that are used for the structural health diagnosis, so propagating these uncertainties into the inverse solution is of paramount importance to instill confidence in the decision making process.  Furthermore, the inverse problem is sensitive to the limited availability of measurement data and may be ill-conditioned and ill-posed.

 

In this project, a novel non-probabilistic approach for using measured vibration responses from civil infrastructure to update numerical models for structural health monitoring was developed, numerically verified, and experimentally validated across a range of several representative applications.  The approach proposes a paradigm shift from the widespread use of optimization of an objective function to constraint satisfaction of constraint equations developed directly from the governing equation for the partially described eigenvalue problem and other mechanics-based structural constraints.  Measurement and modeling uncertainties are incorporated through the use of interval analysis and the constraint satisfaction problem is solved using interval contractors that produce a guaranteed complete enclosure of the feasible solution space for all of the uncertain structural parameters.  The approach was developed into two distinct methodologies: one for prismatic structural members that can be represented with continuous system models, and one for complex structural systems that are typically modeled using the finite element method.  

 

The first methodology is directed toward applications of nondestructive evaluation of cables and hangers in bridges, tie rods in buildings, diagonal bracing, and other structural components where the determination of the internal axial load carried in the member and the degree of restraint at the end of the member can be used to inform structural condition assessment.  Constraint equations were formulated using a continuous system model developed with Timoshenko beam theory, which accounts for the effects of shear deformation and rotary inertia on the dynamic properties of the system.  Since no limiting assumptions were enforced in the derivation of the constraint equations, the methodology is uniquely suitable for application to axial force members with any nondimensional flexural stiffness.  Set Inversion Via Interval Analysis was applied in the methodology to subpave the feasible solution space for the internal axial force, translational end restraints, and rotational end restraints given a set of natural frequency measurements with defined measurement uncertainty.  The methodology successfully identified and quantified the progressive increase in rotational end restraint on the member, while correctly identifying no change in the axial force in the rod or the end restraint at the other connection.  The experimental validation provides evidence that the developed methodology can be reliably used to detect the onset and severity of deterioration and damage in prismatic structural members, including hangers in tied arch bridges where corrosion driven failures have resulted in partial and complete collapses of tied arch bridges.

 

The second methodology is directed toward applications of structural health monitoring of large civil infrastructure, including bridges, buildings, and towers, which are typically modeled using the finite element method that produces a multiple degree-of-freedom system model.  In this methodology, the governing inverse eigenvalue problem was formulated into a set of constraint equations that incorporate the measurement and modeling uncertainties as interval assignments.  The formulation incorporated practical considerations related to the limited availability of sparse measurement data by permitting applications with a limited number of natural frequency measurements and incompletely measured modes.  Additional mechanics-based constraints were formulated to preserve structural properties and connectivity, while an eigenvalue inclusion constraint was also introduced to ensure dynamic consistency between the identified interval model and the experimentally measured response.  The experimental validation included an indeterminate shear building model, where both ill-conditioned and ill-posed cases were successfully solved, and a Pratt truss bridge model that was experimentally tested using a hybrid simulation technique.  The methodology successfully demonstrated the capability to both identify as well as accurately quantify the reduced structural stiffness of the member with the damaged connection across a matrix of ten different experimental scenarios.  To foster dissemination and sharing of the research results, the experimental structural health monitoring data and supporting information on the experiments from the Pratt truss bridge model has been archived and made freely available on the NSF supported DataCenterHub.  

 

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2019
Modified by: Ehab S Al-Shaer
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: One of the more prevalent methods for monitoring the structural health of large civil infrastructure is through the use of distributed networks of accelerometers to measure the dynamic properties of the structure, which are sensitive to the presence and severity of damage and deterioration. In order to relate the measured dynamic properties to the engineering properties of specific components to facilitate diagnosis of the structural damage for decision making, uncertain parameters in a numerical model of the structure are updated such that the model produces optimal correlation with the measured response. However, any errors or uncertainty in the measurements or the numerical model can significantly affect the confidence in the identified structural parameters that are used for the structural health diagnosis, so propagating these uncertainties into the inverse solution is of paramount importance to instill confidence in the decision making process. Furthermore, the inverse problem is sensitive to the limited availability of measurement data and may be ill-conditioned and ill-posed. In this project, a novel non-probabilistic approach for using measured vibration responses from civil infrastructure to update numerical models for structural health monitoring was developed, numerically verified, and experimentally validated across a range of several representative applications. The approach proposes a paradigm shift from the widespread use of optimization of an objective function to constraint satisfaction of constraint equations developed directly from the governing equation for the partially described eigenvalue problem and other mechanics-based structural constraints. Measurement and modeling uncertainties are incorporated through the use of interval analysis and the constraint satisfaction problem is solved using interval contractors that produce a guaranteed complete enclosure of the feasible solution space for all of the uncertain structural parameters. The approach was developed into two distinct methodologies: one for prismatic structural members that can be represented with continuous system models, and one for complex structural systems that are typically modeled using the finite element method. The first methodology is directed toward applications of nondestructive evaluation of cables and hangers in bridges, tie rods in buildings, diagonal bracing, and other structural components where the determination of the internal axial load carried in the member and the degree of restraint at the end of the member can be used to inform structural condition assessment. Constraint equations were formulated using a continuous system model developed with Timoshenko beam theory, which accounts for the effects of shear deformation and rotary inertia on the dynamic properties of the system. Since no limiting assumptions were enforced in the derivation of the constraint equations, the methodology is uniquely suitable for application to axial force members with any nondimensional flexural stiffness. Set Inversion Via Interval Analysis was applied in the methodology to subpave the feasible solution space for the internal axial force, translational end restraints, and rotational end restraints given a set of natural frequency measurements with defined measurement uncertainty. The methodology successfully identified and quantified the progressive increase in rotational end restraint on the member, while correctly identifying no change in the axial force in the rod or the end restraint at the other connection. The experimental validation provides evidence that the developed methodology can be reliably used to detect the onset and severity of deterioration and damage in prismatic structural members, including hangers in tied arch bridges where corrosion driven failures have resulted in partial and complete collapses of tied arch bridges. The second methodology is directed toward applications of structural health monitoring of large civil infrastructure, including bridges, buildings, and towers, which are typically modeled using the finite element method that produces a multiple degree-of-freedom system model. In this methodology, the governing inverse eigenvalue problem was formulated into a set of constraint equations that incorporate the measurement and modeling uncertainties as interval assignments. The formulation incorporated practical considerations related to the limited availability of sparse measurement data by permitting applications with a limited number of natural frequency measurements and incompletely measured modes. Additional mechanics-based constraints were formulated to preserve structural properties and connectivity, while an eigenvalue inclusion constraint was also introduced to ensure dynamic consistency between the identified interval model and the experimentally measured response. The experimental validation included an indeterminate shear building model, where both ill-conditioned and ill-posed cases were successfully solved, and a Pratt truss bridge model that was experimentally tested using a hybrid simulation technique. The methodology successfully demonstrated the capability to both identify as well as accurately quantify the reduced structural stiffness of the member with the damaged connection across a matrix of ten different experimental scenarios. To foster dissemination and sharing of the research results, the experimental structural health monitoring data and supporting information on the experiments from the Pratt truss bridge model has been archived and made freely available on the NSF supported DataCenterHub.
